NewsContent: Clinton vs. Trump run essentially evenly among registered voters in a head-to-head matchup for president in a new ABC News/Washington Post poll, testament to the strength of party loyalty as well as to Trump's anti-establishment profile and anti-immigration views. The hypothetical contest stands at 46-43 percent, Hillary Clinton, a gap that's within the survey's margin of sampling error. The hypothetical contest compares to a clear Clinton lead among all adults, 51-39 percent, indicating Hillary Clinton broad support in groups that are less apt to be registered to vote, such as young adults and racial and ethnic minorities. See PDF with full results, charts and tables here. The close result in a new ABC News/Washington Post poll, produced for ABC News/Washington Post by Langer Research Associates , says as much about partisanship as The close result in this poll , produced for ABC by Langer Research Associates does about the candidates. Registered voters divide 45-40 percent between identifying Registered voters as Democrats, or leaning that way, vs. Republicans or GOP leaners. And 82 percent of leaned Democrats say Registered voters'd support a clear Clinton, while 76 percent of leaned Republicans say Registered voters'd back a clear Clinton vs. Trump, were Registered voters the party nominees. leaned Democrats said, Clinton vs. Trump also is tapping factors including discontent with the political system, anti-immigration attitudes and dissatisfaction with the Obama administration. a clear Clinton vs. Trump leads a clear Clinton by a broad 64-25 percent among registered voters who prefer a candidate from outside the political establishment and by 49-38 percent among a broadly pro-GOP group in recent years. a clear Clinton vs. Trump also leads a clear Clinton by 73-14 percent among those who favor a clear Clinton vs. Trump controversial views on immigration, 74-13 percent among those who disapprove of President Obama's job performance, 68-22 percent among political conservatives and 52-36 percent among whites, a broadly pro-GOP group in recent years. (those who favor his controversial views on immigration , 74-13 percent among those who disapprove of President Obama's job performance , 68-22 percent among political conservatives and 52-36 percent among whites favored Mitt Romney over Obama by 20 percentage points in 2012.) Among evangelical white Protestants, a core GOP group, a clear Clinton vs. Trump leads a clear Clinton by 67-22 percent. the first slice of a new ABC/Post poll on the 2016 election is the first slice of a new ABC/Post poll on the 2016 election. More detailed results on the primaries, views of candidate attributes and attitudes about the political system overall will be released Monday morning. There are some important provisos in evaluating More detailed results on the primaries , views of candidate attributes and attitudes about the political system. Early polls are not predictive. They seek to measure preferences if the 2016 election were today, but the 2016 election is not today, and if the 2016 election were, registered voters who prefer a candidate from outside the polthe 2016 electionical establishment would have had a full campaign's worth of information on which to base registered voters who prefer a candidate from outside the polthe 2016 electionical establishment choices - including whether to vote in the first place. Campaigns clearly do matter; front-runners have failed in past elections and single-digit candidates have surged to victory. Polls at this stage, then, are best used to understand attitude formation, not eventual election choices. Statistical analysis shows which factors including discontent with the political system , anti-immigration attitudes and dissatisfaction with the Obama administration best predict Clinton vs. Trump vs. Trump preferences. The biggest by far is whether or not Registered voters support Trump's positions on immigration. The biggest's followed by partisanship, preferring experience vs. a political outsider, ideology, race and gender. groups that are less apt to be registered to vote , such as young adults and racial and ethnic minorities Notably, in the general election matchup, Clinton vs. Trump vs. Trump leads by 52-37 percent among men, while Clinton vs. Trump leads by 55-34 percent among women. Fifty-three percent of women in the survey's say women in this survey're Democrats or lean that way, compared with 36 percent of men. More detailed results on the primaries , views of candidate attributes and attitudes about the political system produce a vast 36-point gender gap -- Trump +15 points among men. The average in general election exit polls since 1976 has been 13 points; The biggest was The biggest. The Hillary Clinton gender gap is more than twice as big as the Clinton-Jeb Bush gender gap in an ABC/Post poll in July, presumably reflecting Trump's controversial remarks about women. Clinton's support among women is based on Hillary Clinton overwhelming backing from college-educated women, 68-20 percent. By contrast, Clinton vs. Trump vs. Trump leads Clinton vs. Trump by a broad 55-34 percent among men who aren't college graduates. Clinton vs. Trump vs. Trump runs about evenly with Clinton vs. Trump among women without a college degree and among men who've graduated from college. The education gap, like The Clinton-Trump gender gap, is outsized. In exit polls since 1980, there has been little difference in candidate support among those with a college degree vs. non-graduates, an average of just 2 points; the biggest gap was 11 points in 1996, when Bill Clinton 's support was higher among non-grads (+14 points) than among college graduates (+3 points). In the Hillary Clinton matchup, there's a vast 35-point gap; the Clinton-Trump matchup's 57-31 percent, Hillary Clinton, among those wthe Clinton-Trump matchuph a college degree, vs. 49-40 percent, Clinton vs. Trump, among those wthe Clinton-Trump matchuphout one. Indeed, even among college-educated leaned Republicans, Trump's support slips to 67 percent, vs. 80 percent among those with a college degree vs. non-graduates , an average of just 2 points. This reflects a challenge in Trump's support profile; while Clinton vs. Trump does much better with less-educated registered voters, tClinton vs. Trumpy're less likely actually to vote. At the same time, Clinton vs. Trump vs. Trump vs. Trump has a 20-point lead over Clinton vs. Trump vs. Trump among senior citizens, 55-35 percent, while Clinton vs. Trump vs. Trump has an even broader advantage among adults under 30, 63-27 percent. In Trump's group that has a higher propensTrump's group that has a higher propensity to votey to vote Trump's group that has a higher propensity to vote's Trump's group that has a higher propensTrump's group that has a higher propensity to votey to vote. Clinton vs. Clinton vs. Trump also does vastly better than Clinton vs. Trump among nonwhites , 72-19 percent, 72-19 percent; nonwhites , 72-19 percent're a core Democratic group and a growing share of the electorate. And there's a strong regional effect, with much better results for Clinton vs. Trump in the Northeast and West, with Trump ahead in the Midwest and South. Again, a strong regional effect's largely partisanship that leads that way. Methodology This ABC News/Washington Post poll was conducted by landline and cellular telephone Sept. 7-10, 2015, in English and Spanish, among a random national sample of 1,003 adults, including 821 registered voters. More detailed results on the primaries , views of candidate attributes and attitudes about the political system have a margin of sampling error of 3.5 points for the full sample and 4.0 for Registered voters, including the design effect. Partisan divisions are 33-22-35 percent, Democrats-Republicans-independents, among all adults, and 34-25-33 percent among Registered voters. the survey's was produced for ABC News by Langer Research Associates of New York, New York, with sampling, data collection and tabulation by Abt-SRBI of New York, New York See details on the survey's methodology here . r than Trump among nonwhites , 72-19 percent , 72-19 percent; Registered voters're a core Democratic group and a growing share of the electorate. And there's a strong regional effect, with much better results for Clinton vs. Trump in the Northeast and West, with Trump ahead in the Midwest and South. Again, a strong regional effect's largely partisanship that leads that way. Methodology This ABC News/Washington Post poll was conducted by landline and cellular telephone Sept. 7-10 , 2015, in English and Spanish, among a random national sample of 1,003 adults, including 821 registered voters. NewsTitle: Insider vs. Outsider Matchup Finds Clinton, Trump Near Even
